items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have dropped steadily overnight and are now below the flood risk threshold. The forecast is for a predominantly dry day today (3 October 2021) with scattered showers. 

We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Please avoid contact with flood water that may remain on the floodplain and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Flooding is likely to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite and Derwentwater foreshore. Heavy showery rain is forecast throughout Saturday which will cause the rivers and Derwentwater to rise further, with a Flood Warning also in place for Keswick Campsite. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 03/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert has been removed as the risk of flooding has receded and we no longer expect overtopping from waves. Please continue to be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.

The level of Derwentwater is forecast to continue to rise overnight, peaking in the early hours of Sunday morning.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
The rainfall is expected to ease by late evening on Saturday 02/10/2021.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 03/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ravensbourne area in the London Boroughs of Lewisham, Bromley, Greenwich and Croydon
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Bromley, Croydon, Greater London, Greenwich, Lewisham

items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Scattered showers are forecast for today. Further potentially heavy showers are forecast over the next five days which may cause surface water issues and/or cause river levels to rise again. 

We will continue to monitor the situation closely. The weather remains unsettled for the rest of the week and heavy rainfall is possible, and we will reissue this flood alert if required.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. Scattered showers are forecast for today. Further potentially heavy showers are forecast over the next five days which may cause surface water issues and/or cause river levels to rise again. 

We will continue to monitor the situation closely. The weather remains unsettled for the rest of the week and heavy rainfall is possible, and we will reissue this flood alert if required.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the Upper River Wey at Passfield Mill after heavy rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days..
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 03/10/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the Cranleigh Waters. Therefore, the risk of flooding is reducing. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days..
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 03/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The water levels in the River Lymington and Weirs Stream are high and rising. In the last 8 hours, close to half a month’s rain (39mm) has been recorded at Brockenhurst. This is a very large volume in a short period of time. From 19:00 (2/10/21) the river will be much higher than normal and drainage ditches through the New Forest will be flooding land and roads. It will be bank full as it flows through Martin’s Road and Balmer Lawn Road and may cause garden flooding at Balmer Lawn Road. In Lymington itself, the river will rise over the next 10 hours, but we do not expect impacts to property. No significant rain is forecast until Monday which means that the river will remain high this evening and will then fall overnight. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Watersplashes at Brookley Road, Meerut Road, Fatherfield and Butts Road will deepen over the next 24 hours. Do not drive through floodwater. This Flood Alert will be updated at 10:30 on 3/10/21.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible from approximately 9am today, 3 October 2021, around Kinnersley Manor. We expect flooding to affect land and roads. Property flooding is not currently expected.  
 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 5 days. River levels are stabilising around Kinnersley Manor, however standing water may still be present. River levels are still rising at Dorking, Leatherhead and Cobham. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 8pm, Sunday 3 October 2021.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
The risk of flooding from the River Colne has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected today, However there may be standing water seen for several days.
Some isolated showers are possible over the new few days and heavy rainfall is then forecast from Monday night into Tuesday.  This may cause the river to rise again.  This alert will be re-issued if required.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: River levels remain high but are beginning to fall as a result of yesterday's heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected until 2:00 pm today, 03/10/21 around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst. Further showers are forecast later this afternoon. We expect river levels to remain high until 6pm on 03/10/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the Medway. We are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers between Hartfield and Ashurst, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated this afternoon, 03/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur remains high following nearly half a month's rain (30mm) on Saturday. River levels however have now begun to slowly fall. A minor risk of flooding remains that could still affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, as well as in fields and gardens of properties near Mock Bridge. Only isolated showers are forecast Sunday and Monday, which are unlikely to cause river levels to rise significantly, instead the river should return to nearer normal levels Sunday evening (03/10/2021). However, heavy rain is possible Tuesday, which could cause flood risk to return. Some roads may continue to be affected by floodwater, including those mentioned in this message. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:30 03/10/2021.

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible from approximately 9am today, 3 October 2021, around Horley. We expect flooding to affect land and roads. Property flooding is not currently expected.   

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 5 days. River levels are stabilising, however standing water may still be present.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing trash screens and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 8pm, Sunday 3 October 2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
Water levels are high on Windermere, Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel due to the heavy rainfall on Saturday 02/10/2021.
The level of Winderemere and the River Leven is forecast to rise slowly throughout Sunday.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent

items.message:
River levels are rising slowly on the Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent due to the heavy rain that fell on Saturday (02/10/2021).
Flooding to low lying land is possible at the Lower Derwent from Bassenthwaite Lake to the coast at Workington. The Cocker from Crummock Water to Cockermouth. The River Marron from Ullock to its confluence with the Derwent near Bridgefoot.
The Rivers Cocker, Marron and Derwent are expected to remain high today (03/20/2021) but we do not expect any flooding to properties.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/10/2021, or as the situation changes.
